The sudden decrease in platelet count suggests heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), which is a rare but serious side effect of heparin use. Therefore, the next best step in therapy is to discontinue both heparin and warfarin. Alternative anticoagulant therapy, such as direct oral anticoagulants or fondaparinux, should be considered once the patient's platelet count has recovered. Administering vitamin K would not be effective in treating HIT.

A decrease in platelet count during anticoagulation therapy can suggest heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), which can occur in up to 5% of patients. Discontinuing both heparin and warfarin is the recommended approach in this scenario, as well as initiating a non-heparin anticoagulant such as argatroban or fondaparinux. Administering vitamin K is not appropriate as it will only correct the INR, which is not the main concern in this situation. Continuing heparin and warfarin may exacerbate HIT and potentially lead to serious complications.
